section: Collectible Concepts Group, Inc. ('CCGI') and Pivotal Self Service Tech, Inc. ('PVSS'), (the 'Parties' or 'Joint Venturers' if referred to collectively, or the 'Party' or Joint Venturer' if referred to singularly), by this Agreement associate themselves as business associates, and not as partners, in the formation of a joint venture
explanation: The agreement explicitly states the parties are 'business associates, and not as partners, in the formation of a joint venture'. This is ambiguous because a joint venture is generally considered a form of partnership under the law. This contradiction could cause confusion, as the intention to avoid partnership status might not be legally effective given the typical characteristics of a joint venture.

section: The Joint Venturers may be required to make capital contributions to the Joint Venture as needed.
explanation: This is an omission in text. It is not clearly specified how and when capital contributions will be determined to be 'needed', nor does it specify how the amount of contribution will be decided between the parties. The lack of clarity on the process of making capital contributions is an omission in text because it refers to Joint Venturers without detailing a key element of the Joint Venture.

section: Further, each Party elects under the authority of Section 761(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (the 'Code'), as amended and all successor statutes, to be excluded from the application of all of the provisions of Subchapter K of Chapter 1 of the Subtitle A of the Code, and the Parties agree that the election out of Subchapter K of Chapter 1 of Subtitle A of the Code shall, if necessary, be manifested by their execution and filing of all appropriate documentation.
explanation: This statement represents a structural flaw in the legal terms used. While it is permissible to elect out of Subchapter K under Section 761(a), the agreement lacks necessary specificity. It does not detail which party is responsible for executing and filing the election, nor does it specify the timeframe for doing so. Without this detail, it's structurally flawed and hard to enforce.
